item.title: Ticket #1988 (plugins admin / Warning: in_array() wrong datatype, line 90) updated
item.dc:creator: abhay
item.description:
So a simple fix would be to throw in an unserialize() in two lines in ./wp-admin/plugins.php:

line 8 - current: $current = get_settings('active_plugins'); change to: $current = unserialize( get_settings('active_plugins') );

line 70 - current: $current_plugins = get_settings('active_plugins'); change to: $current_plugins = unserialize( get_settings('active_plugins') );

Instead of this bad fix, I'd suggest a better fix that correctly unserializes the bytestream before it reaches the variable in ./wp-admin/plugins.php

item.title: Ticket #1988 (plugins admin / Warning: in_array() wrong datatype, line 90) updated
item.dc:creator: abhay
item.description:
That seems to be a really bad way to fix the error (and it was a bad way to fix it the first time as well) as it doesn't really _fix_ anything except ignore the error. Doing it again will fix the issue of the warnings but will not fix anything if you try to activate a plugin. You'd need to have another precautionary loop around line 10.

I think the issue is that the 'empty' plugin list was stored initially as a string during the clean install procedures and this is what needs to be fixed. I guessing what we see as the string is the empty array represented as a bytestream.

item.title: Ticket #1988 (plugins admin / Warning: in_array() wrong datatype, line 90) created
item.dc:creator: tsimmons
item.description:
in wp-admin\plugins.php, line 90, throws error when accessing the plugins page of the admin. gettype() on the variable in question ($current_plugins) shows it is a string, sted of array.

In 1.5, the fix was to add a precautionary function to check if active plugins is an array or not:

â€‹http://trac.wordpress.org/changeset/2501

item.title: Ticket #1987 (Missing strings in RSS comments) created
item.dc:creator: xibe
item.description:
Some of the strings in the wp-commentsrss2.php are not internationalized.

Line 23 : 

	<title><?php if (is_single() || is_page()) { echo "Comments on: "; the_title_rss(); } else { bloginfo_rss("name"); echo " Comments"; } ?></title>

Line54 : 

		<title>by: <?php comment_author_rss() ?></title>

Line 61 : 

		<description>Protected Comments: Please enter your password to view comments.</description>

Seems like they should read :

Line 23 : 

	<title><?php if (is_single() || is_page()) { echo __("Comments on: "); the_title_rss(); } else { bloginfo_rss("name"); echo __(" Comments"); } ?></title>

Line54 : 

		<title><?php _e("by:"); comment_author_rss() ?></title>

Line 61 : 

		<description><?php _e("Protected Comments: Please enter your password to view comments." ?></description>

item.title: Ticket #1947 (Filter request for Wordpress title wp_title() {without exception}) reopened
item.dc:creator: mani_monaj
item.description:
Let me describe the topic in depth ,

Wordpress uses $month array for month name and use it when generating titles, in Persian(Farsi-Iranian) i18n , our month names are different , we made a plugin for converting dates and it works fine , but we can not change titles because there is no action/filter for that ,

imagine that someone wants to browse www.sampleblog.com/1384/05/ [Persian Mode - It works now] , He/She most get this title Archive->1384->Mordad not Archive->1384->May,

Because wordpress uses $wp_query->query_varsm? for month number and fethes the name from $month array , we should find a way to change $month array JUST in header , before title and restore it before </head>.

As it discussed here and in mailing list , I got convinced it's impossible to add this action hook , but what about a filter hook for wp_title?

item.title: Ticket #1979 (3226 broke rewrite functionality) created
item.dc:creator: filosofo
item.description:
By unsetting the query variables when someone makes an "empty" request, changeset [3226] effectively removes all rewrite rules for the root page. So for example, if you (like me) have a rewrite rule that loads a page instead of the posts when someone requests the domain name, it doesn't work anymore.

My patch solves this by removing the condition that is triggered when the request is empty.

item.title: Changeset [3232]: Regenerate page rewrite rules after creating the first page during install.
item.dc:creator: ryan
item.description: Regenerate page rewrite rules after creating the first page during install.

item.title: Ticket #1978 (Quotes in post title make it into the title for comments_popup_link()) created
item.dc:creator: Viper007Bond
item.description:
If you have a post with quotes in it, they make it into the title for the comments_popup_link() link. This makes invalid code.

Example:

Post title = Announcing "Alphabetical Plugins"

Then this code: 

comments_popup_link('Comments Off', '1 Comment »', '% Comments »');

produces: 

<a href="http://www.viper007bond.com/archives/2005/11/27/announcing-alphabetical-plugins/#respond" title="Comment on Announcing "Alphabetical Plugins"">Comments Off</a>

Solution: htmlspecialchars() or wp_texturize() needs to be run on the post title before it's used.

item.description: If PHP_SELF is empty, use REQUEST_URI when determining pagenow.

item.title: Ticket #1977 (Attachment images don't display in custom attachment templates.) created
item.dc:creator: MattRead
item.description:
Attachments don't display in custom attachment templates. Like attachment.php or image.php, etc...

--FIX--

in template-loader.php add:

add_filter('the_content', 'prepend_attachment');

after line 19:

} else if ( is_attachment() && get_attachment_template() ) {

I would submit a diff but I don't know how too :)

item.title: Ticket #1955 (Outgoing trackback ping could include 'charset' attribute for ...) updated
item.dc:creator: philor
item.description: Hmm. Isn't the bug that we ignore an incoming charset param on the content-type header, rather than that we don't send a charset param in the post data that hasn't ever seen the light of any spec? According to [1734] the WP Japan folks wanted it that way, but I'm not sure quite why, since that was after the August 2004 change in the Trackback spec that called for it on the content-type header, where we do send it.

item.title: Ticket #1961 (Header image generator misreads values, creates invalid and broken XHTML) updated
item.dc:creator: philor
item.description:
Mmm, nice. Easy to do if you know what you're serving, not if you don't. There is a commenting hack that apparently mostly works, except maybe in some older versions of Opera, but 

<style type="text/css">
<!--/*--><![CDATA[/*><!--*/
&
/*]]>*/--></style>

is a touch ugly.

And since the colorpicker uses document.writeln(), it's also tag-soup-only. Maybe just hiding the whole thing based on html_type is the sane way out.

item.title: Ticket #1089 (Feeds do not have immutable GUID) updated
item.dc:creator: ringmaster
item.description:
Version, Milestone changed

RSS2 feed still uses permalink for GUID.

The GUID is saved by 1.5 (that is the fix mentioned above), but was never used by the RSS2 feed (verify this at â€‹http://trac.wordpress.org/file/branches/1.5/wp-rss2.php).

The correct code is currently (1.5 & 2.0) used in the Atom feed:

<?php the_guid(); ?>
